snippet.textDisplay: I love Matt's goofy laugh at the end 🤣 Also, never noticed before how much valley there is in Susan's accent 💃 But in all seriousness, I think Matt did a good job. I hope there are more opportunities for YouTube to answer tough questions like these. I will say that it's a bit annoying to present advertisers as the only moralizing agents, YouTube is one of the most important online platforms to advertise (and especially to certain demographics) and therefore holds a lot of institutionalizing power. What are advertisers going to do if YouTube presses hard on creator freedom in the way they conceptualize categories of content? Well they're going to continue to advertise of course, they're businesses. When it comes to higher values moralizing, YouTube has an important role to play, take lgbtq issues (or sexuality in general) as a salient example. How can it be that YouTube allows for videos discussing such topics in a constructive way automatically gets demonetized, and how on earth can anti lgbtq ads be approved to even be shown on the site, let alone on videos made by lgbtq content creators? I would really like to hear Susan take a twirl at those types of questions.
snippet.textOriginal: I love Matt's goofy laugh at the end 🤣 Also, never noticed before how much valley there is in Susan's accent 💃 But in all seriousness, I think Matt did a good job. I hope there are more opportunities for YouTube to answer tough questions like these. I will say that it's a bit annoying to present advertisers as the only moralizing agents, YouTube is one of the most important online platforms to advertise (and especially to certain demographics) and therefore holds a lot of institutionalizing power. What are advertisers going to do if YouTube presses hard on creator freedom in the way they conceptualize categories of content? Well they're going to continue to advertise of course, they're businesses. When it comes to higher values moralizing, YouTube has an important role to play, take lgbtq issues (or sexuality in general) as a salient example. How can it be that YouTube allows for videos discussing such topics in a constructive way automatically gets demonetized, and how on earth can anti lgbtq ads be approved to even be shown on the site, let alone on videos made by lgbtq content creators? I would really like to hear Susan take a twirl at those types of questions.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think she did a great job. Matt patt honestly asked her alot of really hard questions. She could have voiced her answers more eloquently but being put on the spot like that is hard.

For example, are gamers second class citizens on the platform. Her answer really should have been: you see the things you have mentioned to be segregating gaming content were actually all attempts to help gaming content with the individual extra requirements that gaming content has above e.g vlogs etc. But again that is hard to get out when put on the spot.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Pat, good on you to ask these rough questions to Susan even though she doesn’t wanna give a clear, concise answer in fact dodging the questions as a whole. Kept a clear, composed and professional character in yourself. These conversations and questions NEED TO BE ADDRESSED TO THE HIGHER BRASS OF YOUTUBE. Even YouTube rewind was a middle finger to everyone (especially to those who expected Etika, JuiceWrld and big issues of the year to be at least mentioned) and was basically a copy version of a  WatchMojo video (glad they made their video). These issues on this platform needs to be handled in a more fair way for EVERYONE but not in a way that seems so vague that everyone is affected (I.E. these new harassment policies). YouTube is now becoming more like an advertisement for just big name celebrities, politics and news outlets. And it’s totally not fair for everyone else who have a passion for creating genuine content.

snippet.textDisplay: You get a verification badge when you're famous in order to avoid confusion with fake channels. If you become famous on YouTube, it takes a while to get it while celebrities are already famous, so they get the badge immediately because otherwise a lot of fake channels will be created or already exist while no fake channels of famous YouTubers were created before they were famous.

snippet.textDisplay:
The applause at the end are a good indication of how this went.
Everyone being nice cause she has the power to ruin them all. But rolling their eyes when she isn’t sure if it is pronounced “mi - Minecraft..? Minecraft!” . Obviously a CEO cannot be familiar with every channel on the platform but there is a clear disconnect here. This platform was born from people just making content and putting it out there, and just letting other people do with it what they will. Now the clear priority is to put “insert mainstream personality” into everyone’s recommended, and neuter anything that they don’t agree with. I use YouTube every single day. It really sucks to watch something have its soul slowly ripped out of one rewind at a time.
snippet.textOriginal:
The applause at the end are a good indication of how this went. 
Everyone being nice cause she has the power to ruin them all. But rolling their eyes when she isn’t sure if it is pronounced “mi - Minecraft..? Minecraft!” . Obviously a CEO cannot be familiar with every channel on the platform but there is a clear disconnect here. This platform was born from people just making content and putting it out there, and just letting other people do with it what they will. Now the clear priority is to put “insert mainstream personality” into everyone’s recommended, and neuter anything that they don’t agree with. I use YouTube every single day. It really sucks to watch something have its soul slowly ripped out of one rewind at a time.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm not surprised that Youtube doesn't push gaming content, it's basically pepole watching other people consume a product, and while some gamers provide meaningful commentary, discussion or criticism, I can't think of a reason to really push that sort of thin. How are you supposed to market it?
I guess you could compare it to political channels where people talk about someone else's claims or posts.
It's something a lot of people consume, but it's not exactly marketable.
, people are alread yreally into it and I believe that it's largely watched by children and teenagers who don't have much money themselves.
People who like to watch games find their content easily enough if the community's popularity says anything about it.
snippet.textOriginal:

I guess you could compare it to political channels where people talk about  someone else's claims or posts. 
It's something a lot of people consume, but it's not exactly marketable.

snippet.textDisplay:
Good interview, I would want you to ask about a hard rating system similar to the ratings for TV programs where creators set their own preferred age range and are slapped for violating the guidelines for their rating.
With a hard rating system, all questions of political leanings and graphic content would be effectively baked into the cake. Advertisers would be able to opt into whichever rating system best suit their interests and YouTube can separate themselves from accusations of unfairness.
snippet.textOriginal:
Good interview, I would want you to ask about a hard rating system similar to the ratings for TV programs where creators set their own preferred age range and are slapped for violating the guidelines for their rating.

snippet.textDisplay: The board for YouTube needs to fire this woman and get someone who isn't a corporate shill in there. If YT can't be profitable without traditional media wh0ring, then it sounds like there is no home for many communities on YT anymore, and we need to leave. Problem is, there is next to no competition for YT. Bitchute and the like are infinitesimal comparatively. It's not a very lucrative business the way YT runs it. Who knows? Maybe someone will discover the secret. Maybe there just needs to be more websites dedicated to specific types of video content, like Twitch for gaming.

snippet.textDisplay:
My question for her would be "Why doesn't youtube support xbox gamers?" They need to upgrade their xbox app to allow us to stream to youtube and our channels from our consoles.


As it is, the only way to do it natively from the console is to stream to twitch and them export the archive to youtube. You can't even export from Mixer to Youtube, much less use the youtube app to do it directly.

snippet.textDisplay:
Good interview. It's a shame that she spends most of the time dodging the question and simultaneously assuring you that 'they care'.
You can only be so sympathetic knowing that she has to stay within the distance of a lawyer, at some point there has to be actual honesty involved and less 'brand management'.

The fact is that Youtube refuses to take a stand against advertiser demands and instead of letting them go directly to the channels for deals, they insist on their learning algorithms to sort it out.
Their new "harassment policy" is laughable. We all know that harassment isn't what is actually happening out there, it's people who can't deal with the attention they get, when they say something stupid and/or wrong. At the same time the same people love saying 'freedom of speech doesn't mean freedom from consequence'. Apparently not for them?

Whatever, youtube is a trash platform and it's only getting worse from here.
snippet.textOriginal:
Good interview. It's a shame that she spends most of the time dodging the question and simultaneously assuring you that 'they care'. 
You can only be so sympathetic knowing that she has to stay within the distance of a lawyer, at some point there has to be actual honesty involved and less 'brand management'. 

The fact is that Youtube refuses to take a stand against advertiser demands and instead of letting them go directly to the channels for deals, they insist on their learning algorithms to sort it out.
Their new "harassment policy" is laughable. We all know that harassment isn't what is actually happening out there, it's people who can't deal with the attention they get, when they say something stupid and/or wrong. At the same time the same people love saying 'freedom of speech doesn't mean freedom from consequence'. Apparently not for them?

Whatever, youtube is a trash platform and it's only getting worse from here.

snippet.textDisplay:
I was really expecting you to ask about the burden of proof on claimants of youtube video's and redirecting the monitization of those videos based on just a claim made and nothing else. Why is the burden of proof on the content creator and NOT the claimant? Or about takedowns of videos critical of games by the companies that make them due to "copyrighted content"... why fair use not recognized or enforced on the platform.


I gotta say your questions really just come off as: "Do you care about us?" "Yes" "Are you slanting the system against us?" "No". Your questions felt really weak.
